content.text: The web is more than just text; it is a connectivity graph. Hyperlinks are the 'votes' that tell us which pages are authoritative and which are not.
content.hook: It's not just what you say; it's who cites you.

content.definition: A global ranking algorithm that measures the 'importance' of a page based on the number and quality of links pointing to it.
content.text: Logic: A page has high PageRank if it's linked to by many other high-PageRank pages. It models a 'Random Surfer' who eventually jumps to a new page.
content.hook: The mathematical foundation of Google's success.

formula.description: PageRank algorithm models a random surfer who follows links with probability d, or jumps to a random page with probability (1-d).

terms.meaning: PageRank score of page A - higher means more authority/importance
Damping factor (typically 0.85) - probability of following a link vs random jump
Random jump probability - ensures all pages have minimum PageRank
The i-th page that links to page A (backlinking page)
Set of all pages that have a link pointing to page A
PageRank of page T_i - votes are weighted by the voter's own importance
Total number of outgoing links from page T_i - dilutes the vote
Amount of PageRank passed from T_i to A - distributed among all outlinks

content.definition: A query-dependent link analysis algorithm by Jon Kleinberg.
content.text: 1. Authorities: High-quality sources on a topic. 2. Hubs: Pages that point to many good authorities (e.g. curated lists).
content.hook: A good hub points to good authorities, and a good authority is pointed to by many good hubs.

formula.equation: \begin{aligned} a(p) &= \sum_{q \in B_p} h(q) \\ h(p) &= \sum_{q \in F_p} a(q) \end{aligned}
formula.description: HITS (Hyperlink-Induced Topic Search) computes two mutually reinforcing scores - authority and hub values - that converge through iterative updates.

terms.meaning: Authority score of page p - measures quality as a content source
Hub score of page p - measures quality as a link aggregator/curator
Backlink set - all pages that link TO page p (incoming links)
Forward link set - all pages that p links TO (outgoing links)
Authority = sum of hub scores of pages linking to p (good hubs increase authority)
Hub = sum of authority scores of pages p links to (pointing to authorities makes you a hub)

content.description: How graph weights propagate through links.
Draw 4 websites (A, B, C, D). A links to B and C. B links to C. D links to A. Using the PageRank logic, which site is likely to be the most 'important'? What happens if C links back to D?
